/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas1.JPG Speaker Bios for the Webinar: Methane Emissions Mitigation – Technology and Innovation 2020 5040 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5040 Speakers for the 23 September 2020 GMI Oil & Gas Subcommittee Webinar. /assets/images/event_feature_oilngas0.JPG Methane Emissions from Process Equipment at Natural Gas Production Sites in the United States: Liquid Unloadings 2020 5032 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5032 This study measured methane emissions from liquid unloadings at 107 wells in natural gas production regions throughout the United States. Assuming the data is representative of regions throughout the United States, the study findings indicate that the estimate of methane emissions from liquid unloadings are within a few percentage points of emissions estimated in the U.S. EPA’s 2012 Greenhouse Gas National Emission Inventory released in 2014. PDF English Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas1.JPG 2019 EPA report: Global Non-CO2 Greenhouse Gas Emission Projections and Mitigation 2015-2050 2020 5027 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5027 The report provides emissions projections and estimates of mitigation potential for non-CO2 greenhouse gases through a comprehensive global analysis. PDF English Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas1.JPG Regulatory Best Practices for Vented and Leaked Methane Emissions from Upstream Oil and Gas Operations 2020 5024 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5024 This report provides a summary of the impact of methane emissions, key best practices in the oil and gas industry and a comprehensive review of best-in-class methane emissions regulations. PDF English Oil & Gas,Best Practices,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Best Practices,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas1.JPG Finding the Facts on Methane Emissions: A Guide to the Literature 2020 5022 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5022 This report assesses the range and results of methane studies found in public literature. The review of the studies indicate that results and findings vary significantly highlighting the need to rigorously employ scientific methods and uncertainty principles when evaluating these studies. PDF English Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas2.JPG Reducing Methane Emissions from Natural Gas Development: Strategies for State-level Policymakers 2020 5021 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5021 This report, published by the World Resources Institute (WRI), examines approaches to reducing methane leaks from major natural gas emissions sources in the United States. Information is provided on methane mitigation technologies and policy recommendations are provided for states to consider during the development of future regulations. PDF English Oil & Gas,Technologies,Methane Reduction Strategies,Policy,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Technologies,Methane Reduction Strategies,Policy,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas1.JPG Untapped Potential: Reducing Global Methane Emissions from Oil and Natural Gas Systems 2020 5020 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5020 This report assesses available information on global historical and currently available methane leakage from oil and natural gas systems. The report highlights significant data gaps in emissions data at the country level, identifies disparities in the use of effective emissions factors, projects methane emissions growth between now and 2030, and quantifies the global impacts of actions taken by the top emitting countries. PDF English Oil & Gas,General,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,General,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas0.JPG Assessment of methane emissions from the U.S. oil and gas supply chain 2020 5023 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5023 This document focuses on estimating methane emissions from the U.S. oil and natural gas supply chain using ground-based measurements at the facility level. Using these measurements, the authors estimated the magnitude of methane emissions and determined that for year 2015, supply chain emissions were approximately 60% higher than the U.S. EPA inventory estimate. The authors indicate that this difference may be due to current inventory methods and suggest that the inventory methodology could be improved and substantial methane emissions reductions can be achieved. PDF English Oil & Gas,Methane Reduction Strategies,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Methane Reduction Strategies,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas0.JPG PTAC Canadian Upstream Oil & Gas Eco-Efficiency Equipment and Operations Handbook 2020 5017 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5017 This handbook, developed by Petroleum Technology Alliance Canada (PTAC) provides operations optimization strategies and assists operators, asset managers, and project managers with making efficient and cost-effective equipment selection. PDF English Oil & Gas,Methane Reduction Strategies,Guidance,Guidance, Oil & Gas,Methane Reduction Strategies,Guidance,Guidance,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas3.JPG Best Available Techniques Guidance Document on upstream hydrocarbon exploration and production 2020 5018 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5018 This report focuses on the best available techniques (BAT) and risk management approaches for key environmental issues that arise during upstream onshore and offshore hydrocarbons exploration and production activities. PDF English Oil & Gas,Technologies,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Technologies,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas0.JPG Quantifying Cost-effectiveness of Systematic Leak Detection and Repair Programs Using Infrared Cameras 2020 5019 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5019 This report, published by the Clean Air Task Force (CATF), provides the results of an empirical analysis of data collected on the costs and benefits of leak detection and repair (LDAR) programs at oil and natural gas facilities. The programs discussed in this report use infrared cameras to detect sources of methane and volatile organic compound (VOC) emissions. PDF English Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas1.JPG Sustainability reporting guidance for the oil and gas industry 2020 5025 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5025 This Guidance is intended to be used as a resource to assist company sustainability managers, communications professionals and environmental, health and safety or socio-economic specialists to develop corporate level reporting for internal and external stakeholders of varying audiences for large and small operations. PDF English Oil & Gas,General,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,General,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas2.JPG Potential Cost-Effective Flare and Vent Gas Reduction Opportunities at Selected Production Facilities in Colombia (Operator No. 1) 2020 5026 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5026 This report presents the results of a prefeasibility study to evaluate opportunities to cost effectively reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions through flare and vent gas reduction measures at oilfields. PDF English Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas2.JPG Direct measurements of methane emissions from abandoned oil and gas wells in Pennsylvania 2020 5031 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5031 This study assesses methane fluxes from abandoned oil and gas wells in the state of Pennsylvania in the United States. The study collected direct measurements of methane fluxes from wells using static flux chambers. A review of the collected measurements indicate that methane emissions from abandoned oil and gas wells can be significant and that further research is needed in order to quantify these emissions nationally so that they can be captured in greenhouse gas emissions inventories. PDF English Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,Research,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_coalmines0.JPG July 2020 Coal Mines Subcommittee Meeting Conclusion 2020 5011 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5011 Results from Interactive Poll at the July 2020 GMI Coal Mines Subcommittee Meeting and Upcoming Subcommittee Activities. PDF English Coal Mines,Sector Updates,Presentation,Presentation,Conclusion, Coal Mines,Sector Updates,Presentation,Presentation,Conclusion,
/assets/images/event_feature_coalmines0.JPG GMI Coal Mines Subcommittee Meeting Summary - 23 July 2020 2020 5015 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5015 This document is the summary from the GMI’s 29th Coal Mines Subcommittee virtual meeting held on 23 July 2020. The meeting featured a panel discussion on the “Challenges and Opportunities for Capture and Use of Coal Mine Methane in the COVID-19 World" and was held in conjunction with the online meeting of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Group of Experts on CMM. PDF English Coal Mines,Proceedings,Meeting Agenda/Minutes,Meeting Agenda/Minutes,Meeting Summary, Coal Mines,Proceedings,Meeting Agenda/Minutes,Meeting Agenda/Minutes,Meeting Summary,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas1.JPG Déterminer et évaluer les possibilités d’atténuer les émissions de gaz à effet de serre et d’améliorer l’efficacité opérationnelle aux installations pétrolières et gazières 2020 5014 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=5014 Ce document présente des directives préliminaires au sujet d’une approche pragmatique intégrée visant à déterminer, à évaluer et à faire progresser des possibilités rentables et à impact élevé pour une gestion améliorée des émissions de gaz à effet de serre (GES) et de la consommation d’énergie dans les installations pétrolières et gazières. L’accent est mis avant tout sur les principales sources de polluants climatiques de courte durée de vie (PCDV).

Le rapport s’adresse principalement aux directions d’entreprise, aux exploitants d’installations et aux fournisseurs de services pertinents à l’extérieur de l’Amérique du Nord (en particulier aux endroits où d’autres directives réglementaires sur la gestion de la réduction des émissions de GES et de l’énergie pourraient ne pas être disponibles).

L’objectif premier de ce guide est d’aider à cerner les possibilités d’atténuation rentables des émissions de méthane et d’amélioration de l’efficacité énergétique des opérations, en mettant l’accent sur les types d’installations et d’opérations qui sont le plus susceptibles d’offrir de telles possibilités en fonction de l’expérience pratique. Le guide cerne des enjeux ou des problèmes opérationnels spécifiques qui pourraient contribuer aux émissions non comptabilisées, aux pertes de produits et aux lacunes dans les procédés.		 PDF French Oil & Gas,Best Practices,Methane Reduction Strategies,Guidance,Guidance, Oil & Gas,Best Practices,Methane Reduction Strategies,Guidance,Guidance,

Every two years, the EGBCM develops a report that summarizes emissions and develops recommendations to policy makers on voluntary actions to reduce emissions. A reduction of 2-3 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent are expected for the existing program in Alberta by the end of 2022. Their work with local businesses is expected to reduce waste disposal costs by almost 80 percent, produce fertile humus, increase recycling by 67 percent, and educate employees on sustainable management practices. /assets/images/event_feature_oilngas2.JPG Best Practice Guidance for Effective Methane Management in the Oil and Gas Sector: Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) and Mitigation 2020 4996 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4996 This document provides best practice guidance for methane management within the oil and gas sector and is intended to be a resource for facility owners, operators and government policymakers.

The purpose of this document is to provide information about cost-effective measures for detecting and mitigating methane emissions along the full oil and gas value chain at the company- and national-level. Guidance for developing and implementing practices for monitoring, reporting and verifying (MRV) methane emissions is also provided.

Specific topics covered in the document include:
1. How to improve the quantification and reliability of methane emissions data by incorporating field and country specific data;
2. Best practices for improving and streamlining company-level reporting of methane emissions data;
3. Various options for government policymakers to develop policies, regulations and economic instruments focused on reducing methane emissions from the oil and gas sector; and
4. Contributions of international initiatives to mitigate methane emissions focusing on the Paris Agreement.

The report (see the link below) includes two annexes. Annex 1 provides information on emission sources, typical mitigation techniques, applicable emission detection and quantification equipment, and quantification methodologies. Annex 2 provides a brief overview of commercially available methane emissions detection and quantification technologies.

Several complementary case studies focus on experiences of oil and gas companies with methane emissions inventory, regulatory approaches to methane management, and successful public-private partnerships.

Case studies include:
• Carbon pricing and other regulatory approaches to methane emissions in Alberta
• Regulatory reforms to incentivize methane emission reduction in Kazakhstan
• Public-private partnerships to promote voluntary methane emissions reductions – USA
• Regulations and public private partnership to improvement knowledge about methane emissions and mitigation options – Norway
• Enagás’ CH4 emissions reporting, mitigation and commitment		 PDF English Oil & Gas,Best Practices,Guidance,Guidance, Oil & Gas,Best Practices,Guidance,Guidance,
/assets/images/event_feature_coalmines3.JPG Global Methane Emissions from Coal Mining to Continue Growing Even with Declining Coal Production 2020 4997 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4997 Coal mines are one of the largest sources of anthropogenic methane emissions. As the world produces more coal, coal mines get deeper every year, and methane emissions grow with increasing mining depth. Mine operators also abandon old coal mines, which still emit methane into the atmosphere. The U.S. EPA, in collaboration with the Global Methane Initiative and several other organizations, co-authored this paper that presents projections of global methane emissions from coal mining under different coal extraction scenarios and with increasing mining depth through 2100. The study estimates methane emissions from underground and surface coal production while accounting for the increase in mining depth using several new and compiled data sets. The results show that total methane emissions from coal mining are higher than suggested by previous studies. More importantly, methane emissions from the growing number of abandoned mines increase faster than methane emissions from existing mines. Abandoned mine methane emissions continue through the century even with aggressive mitigation actions. The study concludes that future methane emissions are significantly higher than those in previous studies and that methane resources at abandoned mines will grow regardless of future coal production. This research provides insights for improving future emissions inventories. PDF English Coal Mines,Calculators and Models,Research,Report,Report, Coal Mines,Calculators and Models,Research,Report,Report,
/assets/images/event_feature_steer0.JPG GMC Fact Sheet (2020) 2020 4727 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4727 GMC Fact Sheet PDF English Steering,Global Methane Challenge,Fact Sheet,Fact Sheet, Steering,Global Methane Challenge,Fact Sheet,Fact Sheet,
/assets/images/event_feature_coalmines3.JPG Conducting Pre-Feasibility Studies for Coal Mine Methane Projects Training 2020 4995 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4995 This course introduces principles for assessing the potential of developing projects to capture and/or use Coal Mine Methane (CMM). Website English Coal Mines,Best Practices,Feasibility Studies,Tool/Model,Tool/Model, Coal Mines,Best Practices,Feasibility Studies,Tool/Model,Tool/Model,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas3.JPG Identifying and Evaluating Opportunities for Greenhouse Gas Mitigation & Operational Efficiency Improvement at Oil and Gas Facilities 2020 4925 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4925 This document presents introductory guidance on a pragmatic, integrated approach to identifying, evaluating, and advancing cost-effective, high-impact opportunities to manage greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and energy use at oil and natural gas facilities. The focus is primarily on key sources of short-lived climate pollutants (SLCP).

The primary audience for this document includes company managers, facility operators, and relevant service providers outside of North America (particularly where other regulatory guidance for GHG reductions and energy management may not be available).

The primary aim of this guide is to help identify opportunities for cost-effective mitigation of methane and more energy efficient operations, with a focus on types of facilities and operations mostly likely to offer such opportunities based on practical experience. The guide identifies specific operational issues or problems that could contribute to unaccounted emissions, product losses, and process inefficiencies.		 PDF English Oil & Gas,not a topic,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,not a topic,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas3.JPG Identificación y Evaluación de Oportunidades de Mitigación de Gases de Efecto Invernadero y Mejora de Eficiencia Operativa en Instalaciones de Petróleo y Gas (Spanish) 2020 4926 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4926 Este documento presenta una orientación introductoria sobre un enfoque práctico integral para la identificación, evaluación y promoción de oportunidades costo-efectivas de alto impacto para una gestión de emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero (GEI) y del uso de energía en instalaciones de petróleo y gas natural, con un enfoque centrado principalmente en las fuentes de contaminantes del clima de vida corta (SLCP por sus siglas en inglés).

La audiencia objetivo para este documento incluye a la dirección de empresas, operadores de instalaciones y proveedores de servicios relevantes fuera de América del Norte (en particular para los casos en que no se cuente otros lineamientos regulatorios para la reducción de GEI y la gestión de la energía).

El objetivo principal de esta guía es ayudar en la identificación de oportunidades para la mitigación costo-efectiva de metano y para operaciones con mejor eficiencia energética, con especial atención a los tipos de instalaciones y operaciones en las que es más probable que existan dichas oportunidades, con base en experiencia práctica. También se identifican aspectos o problemas operativos específicos que pueden contribuir a emisiones no consideradas, pérdidas de producto e ineficiencias de proceso.		 PDF Spanish Oil & Gas,not a topic,Document,Document, Oil & Gas,not a topic,Document,Document,

/assets/images/event_feature_biogas0.JPG IEA’s Outlook for biogas and biomethane: Prospects for organic growth 2020 4924 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4924
This report provides estimates of the sustainable potential for biogas and biomethane supply, based on a detailed assessment of feedstock availability and production costs across all regions of the world. These form the basis on an outlook for biogas and biomethane supply and demand up to 2040, based on the scenarios presented in the annual World Energy Outlook.

Key focus areas include how big a role these gases can play in the transformation of the global energy system, where the opportunities and potential pitfalls lie, and what policy makers and industry can do to support sustainable growth in this sector.

Click here to view the report online.		 Website English Biogas,Research,Document,Document, Biogas,Research,Document,Document,

/assets/images/event_feature_agriculture1.JPG Market Opportunities for Anaerobic Digestion of Livestock and Agro-Industrial Wastes in India 2020 4917 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4917 The report on the Market Opportunities for Anaerobic Digestion of Livestock and Agro-Industrial Wastes in India will help inform project developers, policymakers, and other interested stakeholders about the potential for biogas capture and use in India. The report estimates biogas production and emission reduction potential from India’s largest agricultural sectors, and it includes an overview of the uses of biogas and digestate, current biogas policies, technology options, and business models relevant for India. /assets/images/event_feature_coalmines3.JPG Pre-Feasibility Study for Methane Drainage and Utilization at the Pootkee Colliery, Damodar Valley 2019 4900 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4900 This pre-feasibility study was completed to determine the viability of a CMM drainage project at the Pootkee Colliery. Specifically, the study evaluated the technical and economic viability of utilizing long in-mine horizontal boreholes drilled into Seam XII to drain methane in advance of mining, and to identify end-use options for the drained methane. /assets/images/event_feature_biogas2.JPG Estudio de cuencas de biogas, Colección Informes Técnicos N.° 4 (Study of Biogas Basins, Technical Collection, Report No. 4) (Spanish) 2019 4826 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4826 Los Ministerios de Agricultura, Grandería y Pesca de Argentina, junto con la Organización de las Naciones Unidas para la Agricultura y la Alimentación (FAO), han preparado un informe técnico actualizado sobre las cuencas de biogás para promover la energía del biogás y combatir el cambio climático.

The Argentinian Ministries of Agriculture, Grain, and Fish, in conjunction with the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations (UN), have prepared an updated technical report on 15 biogas basins (potential sources of biogas) to promote energy from biogas and combat climate change.		 PDF Spanish Biogas,Bolivia,Research,Document,Document, Biogas,Bolivia,Research,Document,Document,
/assets/images/event_feature_coalmines2.JPG Pre-Feasibility Study for Methane Drainage and Utilization at the Casa Blanca Coal Mine 2019 4821 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4821 This pre-feasibility study was completed to determine the feasibility of a coal mine methane (CMM) capture and utilization project at the Casa Blanca Coal Mine in Colombia. Specifically, this study evaluated the technical and economic viability of methane pre-drainage utilizing long, directionally-drilled horizontal boreholes drilled from within the mine workings. End-use options for the captured CMM were also identified in the study. PDF English Coal Mines,Feasibility Studies,Document,Document, Coal Mines,Feasibility Studies,Document,Document,

/assets/images/event_feature_agriculture3.JPG From Farm to Table to Energy: Co-digesting China’s Urban Food Waste in Wastewater Treatment Plants 2019 4789 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4789 Prepared by the Wilson’s Center China Environment Forum with assistance provided by GMI, the report highlights food waste trends in Chinese cities and assesses the possibilities of redirecting food waste to municipal wastewater (MWW) and sludge-to-energy (StE) plants. This report also highlights some specific gaps that GMI and other organizations could help fill and potential Chinese partners to engage with to highlight the environmental and economic benefits of co-digestion. /assets/images/event_feature_biogas1.JPG Naucalpan, Mexico Waste Characterization Study 2019 4781 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4781 In March 2017, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency – as a lead partner in the Waste Initiative – conducted a waste characterization study at the municipality’s transfer station. The study indicated that approximately 69% of the waste handled at the transfer station could be recycled or otherwise diverted from the landfill, and that more than half of the waste could be used as feedstock in composting or anaerobic digestion projects. The municipality is using the results of the study to inform decision making about the project design and procurement options. Website English Biogas, Municipal Solid Waste,Research,Video,Video, Biogas, Municipal Solid Waste,Research,Video,Video,
/assets/images/event_feature_biogas0.JPG Scaling Sludge Mountains: Breaking Down Barriers for Chinese Cities to Turn Sludge Waste into Energy 2019 4780 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4780 The Wilson Center’s China Environment Forum (CEF) produced this sludge scoping report for the U.S. EPA and the Global Methane Initiative. The report describes drivers that created mountains of municipal sludge, introduces key political and research entities involved in sludge regulation in China, reviews obstacles in adoption of anaerobic digestion, provides a case study of the challenges facing sludge-to-energy projects, and highlights opportunities for U.S. government, cities, and companies to engage with Chinese government agencies. PDF English Biogas, Wastewater,Energy,Research,Document,Document, Biogas, Wastewater,Energy,Research,Document,Document,

/assets/images/event_feature_oilngas0.JPG Project Development Barriers to Methane Mitigation 2019 4761 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4761 Meeting discussion topics. 1. Is your country facing any of the barriers included on the attached list? If yes, please identify the number of the specific barrier(s), as shown on the list. 2. Is your country facing any barriers that are not included on the list? Please identify the barrier(s) and provide a description. 3. For your country, what are the three most significant barriers to implementing methane mitigation projects? 4. Do you have suggestions for how these project barriers could be overcome in your country, or examples of how you are overcoming them? 5. For your country, what are the three least significant barriers to implementing methane mitigation projects? /assets/images/event_feature_coalmines0.JPG Expert Dialogue on Ventilation Air Methane Meeting Report 2019 4749 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4749 The Expert Dialogue brought international experts together in an open, collaborative environment to more thoroughly and candidly explore the technical, economic, and policy barriers that inhibit Ventilation Air Methane (VAM) project implementation. The roundtable developed a discrete list of achievable tasks or action items that could help eliminate barriers to increase VAM project development. /assets/images/event_feature_agriculture0.JPG Using Animal Manure as a Resource 2019 4742 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4742 Anaerobic digestion, or AD, is the biological process that breaks down biological materials like compost or manure into biogas. Livestock manure accounts for 3 percent of man-made methane emissions globally. Methane, when captured and stored, can be used to generate electricity and heat, or it can be processed into natural gas fuel. By capturing the biogas, we are also preventing the release of methane, one of the most potent greenhouse gases, to the atmosphere. Website English Agriculture, Biogas,not a topic,Video,Video, Agriculture, Biogas,not a topic,Video,Video,

/assets/images/event_feature_coalmines1.JPG Coal Mine Methane Mitigation and Utilization Technologies and Project Profiles (also referred to as the Coal Mine Methane Technology Database) 2018 1927 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=1927 This database provides basic descriptions of several key technologies applicable to coal mine methane recovery and utilization, including each technology’s current status and commercial availability. It is intended to be a living document, which will be periodically updated to remain current. The database is an updated and revised version of the original database compiled by Australia’s Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources, on behalf of the Global Methane Initiative. /assets/images/event_feature_coalmines0.JPG A Strategic Approach to Selecting Policy Mechanisms for Addressing Coal Mine Methane Emissions: A Case Study on Kazakhstan 2017 4804 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4804 This article presents the coal mine methane mitigation (CMM) opportunities in Kazakhstan that can help reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the near and medium term. The analysis shows how policymakers in Kazakhstan can leverage existing policies to stimulate utilization by extending feed-in tariffs to cover CMM and by developing working methodologies for companies to obtain emission reduction credits from CMM projects. PDF English Coal Mines,Methane Reduction Strategies,Policy,Case Studies,Document,Document, Coal Mines,Methane Reduction Strategies,Policy,Case Studies,Document,Document,

/assets/images/event_feature_biogas3.JPG Solid Waste Emissions Estimation Tool (SWEET) 2017 4758 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4758 SWEET is a free Excel tool created by the Waste Initiative. SWEET helps users scope emissions sources such as waste collection and transportation, open burning, landfill gas collection systems, organic waste management projects, waste handling equipment (e.g., bulldozers), and waste incineration facilities. It estimates waste sector emissions including methane, black carbon, and several other pollutants. It also evaluates emissions reduction benefits of multiple alternative waste management scenarios. Website English Biogas, Municipal Solid Waste,Calculators and Models,Tool/Model,Tool/Model, Biogas, Municipal Solid Waste,Calculators and Models,Tool/Model,Tool/Model,

/assets/images/event_feature_coalmines0.JPG Pre-Feasibility Study for Methane Drainage and Utilization at the Liulong Coal Mine, Liuzhi District Liupanshui, Guizhou Province, China 2016 4802 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4802 The Liulong Coal Mine was selected for a pre-feasibility study for coal mine methane (CMM) drainage and utilization because of the difficult gas conditions at the mine and expected increases in gas production in coming years as the mine expands. This document summarizes alternative methane drainage options, forecasts future gas production, and outlines recommended steps in pursuing a CMM recovery and use project. PDF English Coal Mines,Technologies,Feasibility Studies,Document,Document, Coal Mines,Technologies,Feasibility Studies,Document,Document,

/assets/images/event_feature_biogas2.JPG OrganEcs - Cost Estimating Tool for Managing Source-Separated Organic Waste - Version 2.1 2016 4757 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4757 OrganEcs aims to help local decision makers in their first evaluation of different treatment options (e.g., composting options and/or anaerobic digestion options). OrganEcs helps users determine the economic feasibility of waste management scenarios by calculating tipping fees, sales of products (e.g., organic compost), and the internal rate of return. OrganEcs use requires expert support. Website English Biogas, Municipal Solid Waste,Calculators and Models,Tool/Model,Tool/Model, Biogas, Municipal Solid Waste,Calculators and Models,Tool/Model,Tool/Model,

/assets/images/event_feature_biogas1.JPG Biogas Wastewater Assessment Technology Tool (BioWATT) 2016 1913 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=1913 The Biogas Wastewater Assessment Technology Tool (BioWATT) provides a quick and preliminary assessment of wastewater-to-energy projects. Through BioWATT, users can receive a specific summary of their biogas production estimates for various wastewater-to-energy technologies, electricity generation potential from the produced biogas, greenhouse gas savings associated with biogas-generated electricity, and more. /assets/images/event_feature_biogas3.JPG Methane Mitigation Matters: Climate Change 2015 4741 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=4741 Methane is a prevalent manmade greenhouse gas that traps 28 times more heat than carbon dioxide (CO2). Reducing methane emissions by recovering and using methane as a clean energy source offers many benefits for the environment and local communities. This video highlights the many ways that reducing methane can benefit the environment and local communities.
  • Decreased greenhouse gases
  • Better air and water quality
  • Improved human health
  • Enhanced energy security
  • Increased worker safety
  • Expanded economic growth
 Website English Biogas, Coal Mines, Oil & Gas,not a topic,Video,Video, Biogas, Coal Mines, Oil & Gas,not a topic,Video,Video,

/assets/images/event_feature_coalmines3.JPG Coal Mine Methane Country Profiles 2015 1926 /resources/details.aspx?resourceid=1926 This document contains individual, comprehensive profiles that characterize the coal and coal mine methane sectors of 37 countries—29 Global Methane Initiative partners and an additional eight coal-producing nations.
